comments.commentBody:
“Alhamdulillah (thanks to Allah), another technological milestone achieved by Pakistan air force.”

Nice way to achieve a technological milestone.

Noah's making huge progress this year as a player and earning the money the Bulls have invested in him. As a Chicago fan, I'm truly happy he's sticking around and providing the character and the talent this team needs.

It's a sign of maturity that he's learned not to worship those he has to compete against.

I caught this read last week on Noah staying with the Bulls: http://www.lowpostnews.com...

Well, this one kicked me up and down and all around until I finally started cheating and even then....way too many possibilities for the legal answers and way too few for the alcoholic beverage ones. MINISTORAGE was about the only hook I could get in.

Liked a lot of words in this: SOCK MONKEY, ABERRANCY, and OPINIONATED.

A few nits: 51D should have been clued as Middle Mgnt because of LIPO for liposuction and 38D is a little off...EYEWINK as opposed to nosewink or earwink?

Somebody help me with 52A, please. I still don't get it.

Good weekend and hoping I do better on the hard ones next week. Three tough, tough days in a row for me.
I recommend Oirschot, a small town, with furniture manufacturers and a beautiful old Catholic church part of which was bombed during WW II.It has alot of WW II history.

How many of us first encountered Will Shortz through Games Magazine? The hidden contest was such a novelty, and great fun. I'm not surprised that Games was the inspiration for this contest.  Solving it correctly was satisfying, yes, but it would be nice to get some acknowledgment! Glad that the teacher of Student @ 38 got to enjoy the admiration of the class, and that he/she's introduced them to the world of word puzzles.
Best of luck, Stu, and whistle a happy tune!

If the parent cares enough to abduct the kid, the kid is in no danger. Even though the other spouse may feel bad, that is just her/his own emotional need. Nothing to do with the well being of the kid. That is insufficient justification to trample on other people's rights.

The root of the problem is not the IRS, it is the divorce and child custody legal system. If that many parents are driven crazy enough to abduct their own children, the fault is obviously with the system. The last thing we need is to add more to it.

Maybe we should use the way they elect the Pope. Lock the couple in room (without their lawyers) and don't let them out until they have an agreement. Cut their ration down to bread and water if necessary. That way we will always get something both side can live with, instead of imposing a solution which is nothing more than the opinion of another person. There are so many cases and so many different judges. There are bound to less competent judges. Mistakes are bound to be made, and some parents will inevitably be forced to take drastic measures!

This robotic adherence to the letter of the law is, under the circumstances, chilling.  When exactly was the use of commonsense for the purpose of making a reasonable judgment rendered subordinate to the letter of the law?  Is there some presumption here that the law has ascended to a state of perfection based on which it should be accorded absolute deference.  The extraordinary historic moment when this occurred somehow escaped my notice.  A reading of the Declaration of Independence will make clear that the American tradition does not place undue emphasis on respect for law above all else.  In point of fact however, the problem here is not excessive adherence to law.  The problem is that the fear of the lawsuits has gained such power that it has paralyzed human reason and kindness.

This should not be such an insurmountable problem.  First, there is absolutely no need to release any financial data.  Any change to the privacy law should limit who is allowed to first request information and secondly who may receive information.  A warrant for someone suspected of a 1st or 2nd degree felony should be sufficient justification.

Taxpayers who abduct their own children should not be entitled to any right of privacy by the I.R.S.
Perhaps President Obama can get bipartisan support in changing the law to protect the rights of missing children.
Why should the I.R.S. have the power to prevent law enforcement from fulfilling its duty to protect and serve?

This is absolutely stunning. I am 51 years old and I have never seen a more egregious example of bad law. There could be absolutely nothing more painful that what these parents face. To have blatant clues available that can't be shared is truly incomprehensible.

This practice, as well as the fact that the wages, as well as the tax refunds, of parents (usually fathers) delinquent in child support, are not seized from these scofflaws, makes a mockery of our justice system and is an abomination towards our children.

This is not news.

It’s how government works.

The right hand is not coordinated with the left hand.

It’s like the section of the Agriculture Department that says eat more cheese while another section says don’t eat cheese.

Just another example of the mindless dysfunctionality of our government and our elected officials who make choices that best serve their needs. Why be an advacate for something that somebody might actually oppose-better to do nothing. Jerry

Good!  Most "abducted" children were taken in a custody dispute or by relatives.  A few will be harmed - just as some will be harmed by custodial parents.  But the greater harm would be a law that is nothing more than yet another erosion of our right to privacy.

Why should the IRS be responsible to hand out addresses and sort through who's who in a divorce or child custody case?  They collect taxes not find missing children.  That's for the courts and police to do.  This is a stupid discussion.

The IRS rules on this subject are an Insane example of Federal Bureaucracy gone Mad ! A legitimate request from law enforcement regarding an investigation should be granted. The only recourse the law enforcement agencies have is to apply for a federal subpoena in each case to access the records needed.

This is chilling.  These are clearly criminal cases, not "family matters." The well-being of the child and obedience to a court order should supercede a kidnapper's privacy rights.  This needs new legislation.

Certainly the life of an abducted child isn't important, where as the privacy of criminals is sacred.

Non criminals can have their privacy violated by the NSA without a care for civil rights.

What is wrong with this country?

Known criminals protected by privacy laws? Why don't innocent children kidnapped by these people enjoy protection under the law? Too bad those who are not criminals don't have the same privacy laws protecting them, ahh democracy.
IRS and census information should never ever be used, even in sympathetic cases such as this. The slippery slope to government overreach and abuse would be too great.

Welcome to the Backward States of America, where empty words like privacy rights, freedom and tradition trump common sense.

America fails its citizenry once again.

Sighs. There are so many positives and negatives to this sort of action.
The positive being that children that have been abducted by the non-custodial parent (many times done as a way to punish the other parent and not because they have a desire to truly be with their children) will be returned home where they belong.
The negative, which is why I suggest to those fleeding domestic violence situations, where the families lives are in danger of being ended, (murdered) and the parent who is taking them is the custodial parent, is that those fleeing, work for themselves. And that if they file a tax return and are recieving a return back, that they have it direct deposited into a bank account that is in a different state than they are. Instead of making many little withdrawls by their debit card, they immediately remove all cash, and put it into a different account.
If legislation was to pass for these kinds of laws, it has so many compounded issues which would go hand in hand.
It would mean that the Government must be ready to step it up when it comes to protecting those that are abused and have had to flee. Making the laws tougher on the abuser who caused for fleeing. Because while it will help protect children that were abducted by the non-custodial parent, it can put a death warrant out on those who have had to flee to save their childrens and their own lives.
If you, or anyone that you know or love is in an abusive relationship, please visit the safty pages at http://www.lindaslaw.org/index.html And if you know a child who is the victim of domestic violence who could use some positive hopes for the future, please have them enter the "Art for Hope" scholarship that I have set up.

http://www.lindaslaw.org/id16.html?ref=nf

Art for hope. A unique scholarship for the children of Domestic Violence. Because lets face it, they are the most innocent of our victims and they need healing too.

Without healing, without a way to be recognized for their place in Domestic Violence, they can become lost, with a greater chance of repeating the cycle of domestic violence. And truly, the only real way to stop domestic violence is to stop it before it happens. We can give the gift of knowledge and healing to our children and their future by allowing them to be heard and recognized now, so that they learn how to break their own place in the circle of domestic violence

And the children that have been abducted by a parent, in either case, are obviously children of Domestic Violence.

May peace find all of us,
Zoe

wonderful
if the IRS gave the info out no one would file
money over morality
that's part of what you get with capitalism until it fails then just press the reset button
Does anybody doubt this? This is our government at work.
